creator: fmfkrauss@mindspring.com
text:
Linux 2.4.18 Kernel.
Attempting to isolate Virus messages into a separate logfile from access_log.
Following statements are at the bottom of my httpd.conf file

LogFormat "%h %l %u %t \"%r\" %>s %b" common
SetEnvIf Request_URI "^/default.ida" attacks
CustomLog logs/attack_log common env=attacks
CustomLog logs/access_log common env=!attacks

The results of the above statments are as follows:
1.  The bad data from the Code Red virus IS being put into the attack_log file.
2.  The access_log file is ALSO getting the virus data in it at the same time.
    This is not what I expected based on the second CustomLog statement.

I have tried to switch the two CustomLog statements around but I get the same
incorrect results.

I did send a copy of this information to the Mailing list users@httpd.apache.org
on 5/8/03 but since no one responded to it, I'm hoping that you could tell me
if I'm doing something incorrect or if there is a problem with the code.

Any testing that you wish me to do, I will be glad to oblige.

Thank you for your assistance in this matter.

Frank Krauss

creator: slive@apache.org
text:
Do you have any other CustomLog directives in httpd.conf?
(grep CustomLog httpd.conf)

Thank you for taking an interest in this problem.

I checked the httpd.conf and there are only these two 
CustomLog statements in it.

Frank Krauss
creator: fmfkrauss@mindspring.com
trawick@apache.org
text:
it works for me with current code (2.0.46-pre1)

can you set up a build with 2.0.45 to see if you still get the problem?

I just wish to give everyone the solution to my Problem.

In my httpd.conf, I had a TransferLog statement that I guess was forcing
all the data to be written to the Log.

When I removed it and re-cycled Apache, The CoustomLog statements are now
working perfectly, just the way I expected them to.

Thank you everyone who may have looked into this problem of mine.

I will now Close the Problem.

Frank
creator: fmfkrauss@mindspring.com
